If we granted it that probably would be stay.

turn.speaker: reynolds
turn.label: Mr. Reynolds
turn.text: If that were granted Your Honor --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: You rather have this grant in the stay and the opportunity to argue then --

turn.speaker: reynolds
turn.label: Mr. Reynolds
turn.text: If it were granted and there were a stay I would prefer to have an opportunity to brief the merits.
I would agree to expedited schedule in accordance with the suggestion of this Court, but I do believe if we get to that stage that at that point we would want an opportunity to brief the merits.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Yes but you don't think you briefed the merits sufficiently for your purposes at this point?

turn.speaker: reynolds
turn.label: Mr. Reynolds
turn.text: We have introduced ourselves only to the question of whether this Court should grant certiorari.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: So your answer though -- you have submit you want to get in before the Court decides the matter?

turn.speaker: reynolds
turn.label: Mr. Reynolds
turn.text: I may well Your Honor, I would like to have time to consider the question as to what additional information on the merits and I would agree to an expedited briefing schedule if we get to that stage.
I believe at the present time that we would be willing to have our brief treated as an opposition to the petition for certiorari.

section.heading: Rebuttal of John W. Vardaman, Jr.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Thank you Mr. Reynolds.
Mr. Vardaman.

turn.speaker: john_w_vardaman_jr
turn.label: Mr. John W. Vardaman, Jr.
turn.text: Mr. Chief justice, may it please the Court.

Mr. Hanover's discussion of the time frame of the acquisition of right-of-way, seems to be based upon the premise that this act was passed in 1968 and it was done before it was passed, but that's incorrect.
The statute was first passed in 1966, and the right-of-way acquisition began in 1967.
So the acquisition of right-of-way began after the statute was passed.
Further in the press release that was put out in 1968, it contains of following statement, “much of the right away leading up the park already has been purchased.”

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: What's the date of the enactment of the provision that required the secretary to think this is the (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: john_w_vardaman_jr
turn.label: Mr. John W. Vardaman, Jr.
turn.text: The provision was enacted in 1966, Section of 4 (f) of Department of Transportation --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And -- since 1966 he has had to make this finding?

turn.speaker: john_w_vardaman_jr
turn.label: Mr. John W. Vardaman, Jr.
turn.text: Yes.
Your Honor the statute doesn't says specificity he shall make the finding.
It says he shall not approve the project unless there is no prudent and feasible --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: That has been on the books since 1966?

turn.speaker: john_w_vardaman_jr
turn.label: Mr. John W. Vardaman, Jr.
turn.text: Yes Your Honor and they say now that the route was approved in the 1968, but the right-of-way acquisition began in 1967 and by 1968 much of it had been acquired.
So they acquired the right-of-way before they approved the project and we shouldn't be made to bear the burden of that rather precipitous action.

Instead we suggest that what they have done by purchasing that right away before making the decision is to present themselves in the court with the (Inaudible) which shouldn't be permitted and the Court should review this decision.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: What you argue is about un-ringing the bell?

turn.speaker: john_w_vardaman_jr
turn.label: Mr. John W. Vardaman, Jr.
turn.text: Your Honor, we are concerned about un-ringing bell and in our concern --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: But can you?

turn.speaker: john_w_vardaman_jr
turn.label: Mr. John W. Vardaman, Jr.
turn.text: Yes we can.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: How?

turn.speaker: john_w_vardaman_jr
turn.label: Mr. John W. Vardaman, Jr.
turn.text: And this record supports it.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: How?

turn.speaker: john_w_vardaman_jr
turn.label: Mr. John W. Vardaman, Jr.
turn.text: We have own file in this case an affidavit of an expert transport plan who is gone out and examined present state of right-of-way acquisition and examined alternatives, has examine studies of this and he makes --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) you agree that those lines a bit bulldozed out all the way up to the park?

turn.speaker: john_w_vardaman_jr
turn.label: Mr. John W. Vardaman, Jr.
turn.text: No Your Honor they haven't been bulldozed out to the park.
The houses have been torn down but there is no clearing up to the park.
The clearing --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Houses are torn down?

turn.speaker: john_w_vardaman_jr
turn.label: Mr. John W. Vardaman, Jr.
turn.text: Yes that land would be redeveloped, it could be resold and redeveloped and what we would suggest would be to go back to point in the route where construction or where clearing of right-of-way is we could use all of the park which has been --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: How long would this redevelopment take?

turn.speaker: john_w_vardaman_jr
turn.label: Mr. John W. Vardaman, Jr.
turn.text: In the affidavit which was filed by our expert he suggested that that these alternatives could be explored and explored in a proper manner on the basis of the information already assembled within 60 to 90 days and this affidavit which is on --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Houses would be rebuilt in how many days?

turn.speaker: john_w_vardaman_jr
turn.label: Mr. John W. Vardaman, Jr.
turn.text: Well, Your Honor I assume that the houses, when the lots would be sold and they would be rebuilt according to the purchaser desires.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: All the way back to where that line is?

turn.speaker: john_w_vardaman_jr
turn.label: Mr. John W. Vardaman, Jr.
turn.text: I am not clear, Your Honor.

This map of course is not part of the record in this case and I am not sure what these various lines are, but it would go back to approximately, I think the houses have been torn down all the way up to the park, but we could, I suppose that park which would be redeveloped would be in the area of that 1.7 miles, something in that order.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What mile?

turn.speaker: john_w_vardaman_jr
turn.label: Mr. John W. Vardaman, Jr.
turn.text: 1.7 miles I believe, but the reason those houses are torn down is because all of this activity took place before they made the final decision on this project and before the route, and before the statutes on which we rely were actually brought into play, because you had to have a final decision on the segment involving the park before these statutes came into play before we had a cause of action.
We filed this lawsuit within a month after that final decision.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What kind of houses are these that have been torn down, what kind of community, residents?

turn.speaker: john_w_vardaman_jr
turn.label: Mr. John W. Vardaman, Jr.
turn.text: Yes Your Honor.
This is area right here I think primarily was a load of middle class residencies --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Now what kind of residency?

turn.speaker: john_w_vardaman_jr
turn.label: Mr. John W. Vardaman, Jr.
turn.text: I would say low to middle class residential area.
On the other side of the park there are very expensive homes that were torn down.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Do you know the total cost of the city in acquiring that right-of-way?

turn.speaker: john_w_vardaman_jr
turn.label: Mr. John W. Vardaman, Jr.
turn.text: No I don't believe that's in the record.

Cost of acquiring of the right-of-way and park is in the record and I think that's 2.2 million dollars, but I don't think it's in the record what it cost to acquire the right-of-way outside of the park.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And to me is what's the state paid to city?

turn.speaker: john_w_vardaman_jr
turn.label: Mr. John W. Vardaman, Jr.
turn.text: That's correct, state, and I don't --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: That would be reimbursement of 90% from the Federal Government?

turn.speaker: john_w_vardaman_jr
turn.label: Mr. John W. Vardaman, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, I assume that's correct.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Were you given access to the administrative record, administrative files of the departments --

turn.speaker: john_w_vardaman_jr
turn.label: Mr. John W. Vardaman, Jr.
turn.text: Not to my understanding Your Honor.

I was led to believe that based on a representation of the document of a Motion for Change of Venue filed in the United States District Court for District of Columbia, that the bulk of relevant documents in the case were in Tennessee, that's why the government sought to change venue.

I was on afternoon, two days before preliminary injunction motion allowed to examine a file in preparation for that preliminary injunction motion which I understood did not constitute anywhere near the number of relevant documents in this case.
And at no time to my recollection was I told that this was the administrative record on which the Secretary acted.
I think further more the question of what the administrative record is, is a legal question, but I was in no time told that this was the record on which he acted.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: This is the controversy surrounding it on page 13 of the government's brief?

turn.speaker: john_w_vardaman_jr
turn.label: Mr. John W. Vardaman, Jr.
turn.text: That's correct.
And I might add that the document -- the document which we did take from that file and put in the record in this case, is a document which had not been submitted by Mr. Speight.
That's the document which shows that the alternative to the north actually takes more residencies, displaces or adversely effects more people in the route which goes through the park.
They characterize that route is taking South-Western university.
As you can see from here it goes past what looks to be a grand front lawn of South-Western.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Suppose you prevail on getting your stay and also having the writ wrapped what ultimate relief (Inaudible) in this Court that you would be entitled to?

turn.speaker: john_w_vardaman_jr
turn.label: Mr. John W. Vardaman, Jr.
turn.text: Your Honor, I think the appropriate relief would be that suggested by Judge Celebrezze that this should be remanded to the District Court to be remand treated as a mandamus action and remanded to the Secretary to have him a formal statement on the record as to what decisions he made and why which the court, District Court could then review.
That that's one alternative otherwise the Court could simply reverse enter an injunction and I assume if the Secretary wanted to he could come back and --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: (Inaudible) reopening of the proceedings and the introduction of evidence?

turn.speaker: john_w_vardaman_jr
turn.label: Mr. John W. Vardaman, Jr.
turn.text: Oh, I certainly would Your Honor.

I would suggest that when we were back that the summary judgment would be reversed and when we were back in the District Court we would be entitled to whatever type of trial that we were entitled in issue.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Would it be a trial in which alternatives other than those marked on that could be considered in your judgment?

turn.speaker: john_w_vardaman_jr
turn.label: Mr. John W. Vardaman, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, I think it should be Your Honor.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Do you think this process, this hypothetical process, is complicated for the fact what the Secretary who made these decision is no longer the Secretary?

turn.speaker: john_w_vardaman_jr
turn.label: Mr. John W. Vardaman, Jr.
turn.text: Your Honor it's -- it is undoubtedly complicated somewhat by that, but that's one of the reasons that it's necessary to impose upon this – the people and make these decisions if the requirement that they be incorporated in some type of written orders so that as the administration change whatever was decided will be recorded there.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Congress did easily have provided that could they not, as they do in many other situations, administrative situations?

turn.speaker: john_w_vardaman_jr
turn.label: Mr. John W. Vardaman, Jr.
turn.text: They certainly could have, however --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: But they did --

turn.speaker: john_w_vardaman_jr
turn.label: Mr. John W. Vardaman, Jr.
turn.text: However, the fact that they didn't, I think should not be regarded, that the silence in Congress should not be regarded as provision not to do it, particularly where Congress has made these actions specifically reviewable by the courts under the administrative procedure.

I would note that the people who did make the original decisions or decisions in 1968 are available to testify and they are willing to testify and under the decision below, we are not permitted to ask them what decisions they make.
That's another reason we suggest a decision below --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But the secretary has been arguing about the Federal-Aid Highway Act that after the effective date of the Federal-Aid Highway Act 1968, the Secretary shall not approve any programs?

turn.speaker: john_w_vardaman_jr
turn.label: Mr. John W. Vardaman, Jr.
turn.text: That's that's a correct statement of the Section 138 of the Federal-Aid Highway Act.

Now, if Your Honor would examine what the Section 4 (f) of the Department of Transportation Act, not as it presently appears, as it appeared when enacted in 1966, the operative provisions are verbatim with the provision.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: You have to say after the effective date of the Federal-Aid Highway Act?

turn.speaker: john_w_vardaman_jr
turn.label: Mr. John W. Vardaman, Jr.
turn.text: No.
I mean that the provisions which we were discussing, shall not approve unless there are no --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: What highways?

turn.speaker: john_w_vardaman_jr
turn.label: Mr. John W. Vardaman, Jr.
turn.text: Shall not approve a project or program, I believe is the statutory language.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, do you think that if the Federal-Aid Highway Act had never been passed, you would still be here on the same case?

turn.speaker: john_w_vardaman_jr
turn.label: Mr. John W. Vardaman, Jr.
turn.text: Under the Department of Transportation Act.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And you don't think the Federal-Aid Highway Act has superseded that and gave a new date for it --

turn.speaker: john_w_vardaman_jr
turn.label: Mr. John W. Vardaman, Jr.
turn.text: No, Your Honor, the Department of -- let me explain just briefly the way these acts were passed.

There was at one time when Department of Transportation Act was passed, Section 4 (f) was included and it said, “the Secretary shall not approve any project unless there are no feasible and prudent alternatives or unless the design includes all possible planning to minimize harm.”
There was at that time a Section 138 in the Federal-Aid Highway Act that was slightly different.

In 1968, it was decided to make those identical and there was an amendment in 1968, but the requirements concerning feasible and prudent alternatives, and the requirements concerning all possible planning were in the 1966 Act, were applicable to this case and indeed the Department of Transportation considered them applicable to this case.
Now Mr. Bridwell testified before Congress on one occasion concerning certain aspects of this case and he said, Section 4(f) came into play.
So it was the Department's interpretation of the Act as well as ours.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Does this highway connect or going through the city, connect on the east end with the through highway and of course, (Inaudible) to highway?

turn.speaker: john_w_vardaman_jr
turn.label: Mr. John W. Vardaman, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Which, what number is it?

turn.speaker: john_w_vardaman_jr
turn.label: Mr. John W. Vardaman, Jr.
turn.text: This is I-40.
It's a transcontinental highway and as I understand it goes --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: As far as that highway is concerned it's (Inaudible) not only to take to get through the city and not have to get there (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: john_w_vardaman_jr
turn.label: Mr. John W. Vardaman, Jr.
turn.text: Well, I am not even sure if that's a question in this particular case Your Honor, because the -- for people traveling on an interstate through a traveling interstate, they don't have to go on this highway.
There is under construction now a circumferential which will go --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Which is we have here --

turn.speaker: john_w_vardaman_jr
turn.label: Mr. John W. Vardaman, Jr.
turn.text: I think it's located closer, but basically the idea is the same so that those that are traveling through can – would be able to go on a circumferential and avoid going downtown.
I think that's that's the way those --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Who is started, who offered this bill amendment that provides for this?

turn.speaker: john_w_vardaman_jr
turn.label: Mr. John W. Vardaman, Jr.
turn.text: Senator Yarborough of Texas did.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: This improvement, widespread improvement behind it or do you know?

turn.speaker: john_w_vardaman_jr
turn.label: Mr. John W. Vardaman, Jr.
turn.text: At that time, this was one of the first bills which was passed to articulate a purpose and to begin a program in environmental protection.
That movement has been building up over the year since 1966 and now there is wide support for this bill and every other type of bill, practically every other type of --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: To protect the parks?

turn.speaker: john_w_vardaman_jr
turn.label: Mr. John W. Vardaman, Jr.
turn.text: To protect parks, to protect recreation areas, to protect our natural resources.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: As I understand you would say in answer to a question by Mr. Justice Black that if you prevail in this case and the summary judgment is set aside, the case is remanded to the District Court, that then it will be up to the District Court to consider and weigh the merits of the various alternative routes?

turn.speaker: john_w_vardaman_jr
turn.label: Mr. John W. Vardaman, Jr.
turn.text: No, I didn't mean to say that.
What I meant to say is that in passing on the Secretary's judgment, the District Court may determine whether he applied the statute incorrectly in not choosing other alternatives.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: The question would be whether or not the Secretary complied with the statute?

turn.speaker: john_w_vardaman_jr
turn.label: Mr. John W. Vardaman, Jr.
turn.text: Well, that's correct.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: It's not up to the District Court surely --

turn.speaker: john_w_vardaman_jr
turn.label: Mr. John W. Vardaman, Jr.
turn.text: Oh!
No, that's -- I really Your Honor -- no it's not up to the District Court.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: I want to make sure I understood you --

turn.speaker: john_w_vardaman_jr
turn.label: Mr. John W. Vardaman, Jr.
turn.text: That's correct.
The question will be whether he complied with the statute?
Thank you.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Thank you Mr. Vardaman, Mr. Reynolds, Mr. Hanover.
The case is submitted.
